invisibility_through_pattern.statement: In an algorithmic world, the way to disappear is not to be absent, but to look exactly like what the system expects to see.
manifestations: Ghost containers looking 'normal' to port AI by having correct sensor signatures
Pharmacy robbers invisible during system reboots they trigger
Burglars knowing when apartments are empty by being algorithmic, not observant
Service workers invisible to wealthy residents, making them perfect data sources
Criminals hiding in the noise of legitimate patterns

character_connections.Sara: Feels invisible as her profession becomes obsolete to automation
character_connections.Yusuf: Uses his understanding of how systems see (or don't see) Rosengård residents
character_connections.Chen: Hides in plain sight as 'just another' logistics coordinator
character_connections.Katarina: Cleaning workers are invisible; she weaponizes that invisibility

invisibility_through_pattern.resolution: Partial. Human insight (Sara's) can see what algorithms miss, but it doesn't scale.

data_exhaust_as_weapon.statement: Every system that watches you creates information that can be used against you. Your patterns are the crime scene before the crime happens.
manifestations: Smart locks tracking resident schedules enable burglaries
Port automation patterns reveal when containers won't be inspected
Customer service automation creates predictable security vulnerabilities
Even police patrol patterns become exploitable data
Legitimate work (cleaning, delivery) generates criminal intelligence

character_connections.Sara: Her investigation generates data that could be exploited - the hunters are hunted
character_connections.Emil: Understands this intellectually but it drives his cynicism
character_connections.Criminals: All three criminal operations exploit data exhaust from legitimate systems

data_exhaust_as_weapon.resolution: Unresolved. The surveillance infrastructure that creates data exhaust is the system itself. Can't solve it by arresting individuals.

human_obsolescence_vs_necessity.statement: Algorithms are replacing human judgment everywhere, but only human insight can see what the algorithms miss. We're obsolete and essential at the same time.
manifestations: Automated port systems efficient but exploitable
Police AI tools helpful but create overreliance
Sara's detective work vs Emil's technical analysis - need both
Criminals use algorithmic tools but need human creativity to exploit them
Service workers replaced by automation, but their human access is valuable to criminals

character_connections.Sara: Her father made obsolete by automation. She fears the same fate.
character_connections.Emil: His technical skills racing against obsolescence as criminals innovate faster
character_connections.Yusuf: Talented but couldn't get hired - algorithmic screening rejected him
character_connections.Katarina: Lost teaching job to budget cuts, now in precarious gig economy
character_connections.Chen: Sophisticated logistics coordinator reduced to helping smugglers to survive

human_obsolescence_vs_necessity.resolution: Affirmed. Sara wins by doing what algorithms can't - unpredictable trust and ethics. But individual victories don't solve systemic displacement.

secondary_themes.class_and_surveillance: The wealthy buy privacy; the poor are surveilled. But surveillance creates exploitable data that enables crimes against the wealthy. The surveillance state serves and victimizes everyone.
secondary_themes.immigrant_marginalization: Chen and Yusuf both show how economic and social marginalization pushes talented people into criminal economies. The system creates its own enemies.
secondary_themes.professionalization_of_crime: Crime used to be violent and obvious. Algorithmic crime is white-collar, technical, and invisible. This makes it more insidious and harder to prosecute.
secondary_themes.collaborative_vs_competitive: Sara and Emil succeed through collaboration. Criminals mostly work alone. Human connection is the advantage against algorithmic isolation.

asked_not_answered: Can traditional law enforcement adapt fast enough to algorithmic crime?
Is algorithmic crime a symptom of economic inequality, and if so, is prosecution just?
What happens when the surveillance infrastructure becomes the crime infrastructure?
Are we creating a world where only criminals and corporations understand the systems that govern us?
answered_partially: Can human insight beat algorithmic prediction? (Yes, sometimes, but it doesn't scale)
Should we trust the systems we don't understand? (No, but we have to use them anyway)
Is there ethical algorithmic crime? (No, but there are sympathetic algorithmic criminals)

symbolic_elements.the_ghost_container: Physical object that's invisible to algorithms. Represents how presence and absence are algorithmic constructs.
symbolic_elements.the_phone_running_fake_signatures: Machine pretending to be another machine. Identity is just data patterns.
symbolic_elements.the_cleaning_workers: Literally invisible to residents. Their visibility is our vulnerability.
symbolic_elements.rosengard: Marginalized neighborhood full of talent the system wastes. Represents algorithmic discrimination in geographic form.
symbolic_elements.turning_torso: Malmö's iconic modern building. Smart, surveilled, vulnerable. The future of housing is the future of crime.
symbolic_elements.limhamn_harbor: Where global capitalism meets local exploitation. Automation enables crime at scale.

tonal_elements.nordic_noir_meets_cyberpunk: Cold, clinical, morally gray. Technology is the new noir landscape.
tonal_elements.procedural_realism: Show the work. Investigations are methodical, not magical.
tonal_elements.empathy_without_excuse: Understand criminals without excusing crimes. Understand systems without surrendering to them.
